question: What time is it?
answer: Four. Why?

question: This milk is bad.
answer: When did you buy it?

question: Tuesday? I don't know. What's today?
answer: Monday. There's a deli on Broadway.

question: Nothing closer?
answer: Nothing that's open.

question: Is it that bad?
answer: I don't know. You're the one who said it was bad.

question: Tired?
answer: No, I've been up since four. I've got a big scene today and I'm kind of nervous.

question: "Ellen talks to Mom."
answer: Have you read the script?

question: No. It's on the callsheet.
answer: Oh. Well, it's pretty emotional. I tell my mother I never felt she really loved me.

question: You're going to yell at each other?
answer: I don't know. I'm just going to go with how I feel. Which is the scary part. I'm very close to this character.

question: Problems with your own mom?
answer: Yes. But she died before I, well before we could reconcile...

question: You were great in that Richard Gere movie.
answer: Thanks.

question: Thanks.
answer: Ellen, I have no memory of this whatsoever. Ellen... Ellen I have NO memory of this whatsoever.

question: Good morning, "Mom."
answer: Morning.

question: Sleep well?
answer: Not a wink.

question: Look, I'm not blaming anybody, Wanda. I'm just saying we left last night and I knew we didn't get that scene.
answer: I'm sorry, I thought it was a great scene, Nick.

question: It was OK; and it's going to be alright. But I'm not settling for OK today. This is a big scene and I'm not leaving till we get it.
answer: Whatever it takes, Nick. We're here for you.

question: Alright, here's what I'm thinking. Wolf, I want to do the whole scene in one shot.
answer: It's been done.

question: I know that but I'd like to try it anyway.
answer: Handheld.

question: No, dolly. We go from Close-up to Wide-shot and back to Close-up in the same shot.
answer: I'll use the 35, minimize distortion; I'll light it all from the ceiling. It could be kind of great.

question: Dad hit me first and knocked me down. It didn't hurt that much but I started crying anyway, hoping he would leave me alone. He went over and started hitting Danny.
answer: Ellen, I have no memory of this whatsoever.

question: You were just standing there looking at me. Then you pulled me up and said, "You're not hurt." Like I was disgusting for faking, for doing the only thing I could think of to keep him from hitting me again.
answer: I was worried about Danny.

question: You do remember.
answer: He was smaller than you.

question: I'm sorry about all this, Nicole.
answer: It's not your fault, Nick. Is there a way to use some of the earlier takes?

question: Not unless I change the shot; do a cutaway of Cora or something and intercut the takes. I don't want to do that. It's a really nice shot and what you're doing is incredible.
answer: Thanks, Nick.

question: How was she in that Richard Gere movie?
answer: So-so.

question: Her career really took off, didn't it?
answer: I saw her in a Michael Bolton video.

question: Then you pulled me up and said, "You're not hurt." Like I was disgusting for faking, for doing the only thing I could think of to keep him from hitting me again.
answer: I was worried about Danny.

question: You do remember.
answer: He was smaller than you.

question: Well, when did he ask you?
answer: Yesterday, when I was helping him check into his hotel.

question: What, the guy can't even check into a hotel by himself?
answer: Listen, Wolf, having Chad Palomino in this movie will benefit us all. If being there when he checks into his hotel makes him feel better, then I'm happy to do it.

question: Well, how did it come up?
answer: He asked me if I liked jazz, I said yes, and he suggested we meet tonight at a jazz club.

question: I like jazz.
answer: He did not invite you.

question: Why are you wearing perfume to work?
answer: Because I feel like it.

question: You didn't wear it yesterday.
answer: Oh, stop it. You're acting like a child.

question: My eye!
answer: Oh, God. Sweetheart, are you alright?

question: Do I look alright?!
answer: Let me see. Christ, we're going to be late.

question: Should we call up to the room again?
answer: He said he'd be right down. Tired?

question: I'm exhausted. I dreamt I was on the set all night. I was just trying to do one shot and everything kept going wrong.
answer: That's an anxiety dream. Are you anxious about something?

question: I don't know. Sometimes I wonder what the hell I'm doing in this business. It's all just one compromise and disappointment after another. I don't know if I have the personality for it.
answer: Sounds kind of like an identity crisis.

question: Maybe you're right. Who am I? What am I really capable of? Maybe I should just get a job teaching at a women's college somewhere.
answer: How'd you get into cinematography?

question: I'm not a cinematographer.
answer: You're not?

question: No. I'm directing this movie.
answer: How'd you get into directing?

question: I got two films coming up right after yours, Nick. One I play a rapist that Michelle Pfeiffer falls in love with. The other I'm kind of a sexy serial killer who shacks up with Winona Ryder.
answer: That's great, man.

question: Yeah, but I'm not into that hostess twinkie shit, Nick.
answer: Hostess twinkie?

question: That Hollywood shit. It's all fluff, man. These are the kind of movies I want to do, right here.
answer: I'm glad you feel that way, Chad. And I just want to tell you, I'm really happy we can work together.

question: Hey, me too! You're a great director, man. Your films are wacked! And I'm gonna be watching you, buddy. Like a hawk. I want to learn from you, Nick. I'm gonna pick your brain.
answer: Good. Then you can pick my nose.

question: See what I mean? You're wacked. Hey, what are we sitting here for?
answer: We're waiting for Nicole.

question: Nicole? She's takin' a tax --
answer: What?

question: Probably taking a shower or something. Hey, how was her shower scene in that Richard Gere movie?
answer: Good.

question: I think we got nudity today.
answer: It just says "Scene Six

question: Could be a kiss with nudity.
answer: I like Ellen. She's my type.

question: Why is that?
answer: She's pretty. Smart. Kind of kooky.

question: Maybe I'll give her a part. That's right; I'm makin' my own movie pretty soon.
answer: Oh yeah?

question: Yup. Feature. I brought my script. Palomino's perfect for the lead. I'm going to give it to him right during lunch. Maybe right after.
answer: Alright.

question: Got to be aggressive. You want to shoot it?
answer: Sure.

question: You ever shot anything?
answer: No.

question: Jesus, what are you doing? How'd you get here?
answer: Took a taxi.

question: Oh. We've been waiting in front of your apartment for half an hour.
answer: God, I'm sorry, Nick. Something came up. I forgot to call. I'm sorry, I feel like such an asshole.

question: You're just saying that because you have Preparation H on your face.
answer: I never should have gone out last night. I hate jazz. God, I look terrible.

question: No you don't.
answer: Don't bullshit me, Nick.

question: Well, then
answer: It sounds like the champagne talking.

question: I've loved you from the moment we met.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: We were working together. I didn't want anything to interfere.
answer: God. And all this time I thought...

question: I've always admired you from afar.
answer: Admired? That sounds rather professional.

question: Well, then
answer: It sounds like the champagne talking.

question: I've loved you from the moment we met.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: We were working together. I didn't want anything to interfere.
answer: God. And all this time I thought...

question: "Me, me, me," that's the cue. Let's shoot; I'm stoked!
answer: One second, Chad. Chad, how would you describe this scene, in one word?

question: Great. It's a great scene, man.
answer: No, I mean it's a love scene. Right?

question: Definitely.
answer: These two people really love each other. And we want to see that, especially in the kiss.

question: Hey, say no more, Chief.
answer: Nicole?

question: I've always admired you from afar.
answer: Admired? That sounds rather professional.

question: Well, then
answer: It sounds like the champagne talking.

question: I've loved you from the moment we met.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: We were working together. I didn't want anything to interfere.
answer: God. And all this time I thought...

question: Yeah, Chad. What happened; I thought you were going to hold back till "me"?
answer: The more I thought about it the more it didn't seem right. And I'm thinking, watch me here, instead of coming around the bed, what if I just slip here like this and do the whole scene lying down?

question: I don't know, that seems a little...
answer: Hey, I'm just throwing out ideas here. Trying to get the juices flowing.

question: I've always admired you from afar.
answer: Admired? That sounds rather professional.

question: Well, then
answer: It sounds like the champagne talking.

question: I've loved you from the moment we met.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: Thanks.
answer: My pleasure. Sugar?

question: Just a bit.
answer: You like jazz?

question: Very much.
answer: Maybe we could go hear some tonight.

question: It's going well I think. Don't you think?
answer: Very well. What time do you think we'll finish?

question: Early I hope. I'm going to a jazz club tonight.
answer: Really? So am I. He's wonderful, isn't he?

question: Chad?
answer: He's so natural, like... air. I wonder what his sign is. Do you know, Nicole?

question: Hey, Chad.
answer: Hey, whatya say.

question: I'm Bob. I'm lighting this show.
answer: Chad Palomino; Actor.

question: I know.
answer: Hey, what's your name?

question: Maurice! Hey, Maurice Chevalier! Any relation? Probably not. Hey, smoking crew guys, really.
answer: Hey thanks, Chad. Actually I wrote a script.

question: Oh, yeah? Hey, Bill. See that light over there?
answer: Uh, yeah.

question: Would you care to have a drink tonight? Hey, Nicole, what do you say you and I have a drink tonight?
answer: Oh, Nick! I'm sorry!

question: That's OK, no problem. I'm just slapping a little water on my face. So, it's going pretty good, huh?
answer: Is it? Something feels off.

question: Yeah, you seem a little tense.
answer: Do I?

question: But don't worry about it. Just take your attention off yourself and put it on Chad. Work off him a little more.
answer: OK, I'll try that.

question: And listen, I know he's no Olivier. But he's got something, don't you think? Kind of a natural presence.
answer: Oh yes, he's very natural.

question: So Nicole... anything else I can help you with?
answer: Actually there is. Could you maybe ask him to brush his teeth?

question: My eye is killing me.
answer: Put your eyepatch on.

question: I lost it.
answer: Is that little light set yet?

question: That little light was set ten minutes ago.
answer: Get me the A Team in here right away. Nick, Nicole, and Mr. Palomino. Why didn't you tell me?

question: Hey, you're not worried about the time, I'm not worried about the time.
answer: Oh, I am very worried about the time!

question: I know you are.
answer: What is that supposed to mean?

question: What do you think it means?!
answer: I don't know what it means!

question: Oh yes you do, you know exactly what it means.
answer: I have no idea what you're talking about! Why are you --

question: You don't understand me, Wanda! You have no idea --
answer: I don't understand you?!! All I do is take care of you!!!

question: Fine. I'll get my own. Nick, send someone out for an eyepatch. I'll fucking pay for it myself.
answer: Listen, Chad. I didn't want to say this in front of Wolf but it makes you look a little... gay.

question: Really?
answer: Yeah, a little bit.

question: I've always admired you from afar.
answer: Admired? That sounds rather professional.

question: Well, then
answer: It sounds like the champagne talking.

question: I've loved you from the moment we met.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: I'm out of here, man!
answer: What's the matter?!

question: I like you, but I made a big mistake taking this part. Have someone call me a cab.
answer: Wait a second, Chad. Just talk to me. What's going on!?

question: God, and all this time I thought... Why did you cast her? She sucked in that Richard Gere movie!
answer: You're right. She is not the best actress in the world. I see that now but you've got to help me, Chad. I'm asking you to please help me here. We've got to get through this somehow.

question: I'll tell you what this is about, man. You know why she took a cab this morning?
answer: Something came up.

question: Nicole, listen...
answer: Nick, it's my fault the scene isn't working. I apologize. Chad, I apologize to you too. I'm completely unfocused here and I think you're absolutely right; what we need to do is loosen the scene up somehow.

question: What would you like to do?
answer: I was wondering if we could try improvising the scene. More along the lines of what Chad has been doing. Maybe that would help me find something.

question: I've always admired you from afar.
answer: Have you? That's, wow; that's incredible. But that sounds kind of professional doesn't it? Admired?

question: You're right. How does despised sound?
answer: Great! What's it mean?

question: It's sort of like I think you're a piece of shit.
answer: That sounds like the champagne talking.

question: It's not. I really do think you are a piece of shit.
answer: No, you don't. You love me.

question: The fuck I do. I can't stand looking at you!
answer: Then I guess I have nothing else to say.

question: No, I think you have a lot more to say, Damian.
answer: Well, I am surprised you feel this way, Ellen. I always thought you admired --

question: That's not what I meant. You should tell everyone what you just told Nick behind the set.
answer: Hey, this isn't part of the scene.

question: Say it anyway
answer: See, Nick! I told you this was about rejection!

question: You fucking scumbag! You think I give a rat's ass about you?! I was there to get laid and even that was a joke!
answer: You know, you are really starting to piss me off!

question: OK, guys, I think we can stop there.
answer: You bet your ass we can stop! Wanda, call me a cab!

question: Hold on, Chad. Let's just try to calm down.
answer: Fuck you. I'm out of here, man. This movie is bullshit.

question: Now wait a second, Chad. There's no reason for hostility.
answer: Shut up, you fucking loser. The only reason I took this part was because someone said you knew Quentin Tarantino! You're nowhere, man.

question: Hey, you want to go? Go! I'm sick of your shit, you hostess twinkie motherfucker!
answer: What'd you call me?

question: You heard me.
answer: Say it again.

question: Nicole, I'm sorry. I didn't mean it. You were great in that Richard Gere movie.
answer: Shut up. You're no different than he is. You lie, you're deceitful...

question: I'm not lying. Christ, I tell everyone how great you are. I've got nothing but respect and admiration for you.
answer: Oh God, now you're doing your own fucking script.

question: Well, why do you think I wrote it?!
answer: I have no idea!

question: It's about you. It's about how I feel about you.
answer: Christ, did you get a bump on your head, Nicky. 'Cause you're talking like an idiot.

question: Nicole. I've loved you since the day we met.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: I didn't want anything to get in the way of us working together.
answer: God, and all this time I thought... Oh, God.

question: Don't go out that door!
answer: Why not?

question: It's part of the set, goddamnit. Now go around.
answer: Next time. This is an emergency.

question: Has Ellen showed up yet? Get her into wardrobe right away. No! Scene six; Scene five has been postponed. I'm not going to say it again; Mr. Palomino is not working today. Now where is that smoke machine!
answer: Oh. Sorry.

question: Just as we pull up to your apartment Palomino suddenly says he feels so sick he can't work today.
answer: God. Was it something he ate?

question: I don't know.
answer: Can he work tomorrow?

question: Did I just offend him?
answer: What did you say?

question: "Short notice?"
answer: Come on; that was nothing. I'm the one who called him "Toto." Jesus, I'm out of it. I dreamt I was on the set last night too.

question: Oh yeah?
answer: Yeah. You were in the dream.

question: Was I freaking out?
answer: Actually, you were.

question: That's great
answer: Nick...

question: That's where the gas goes.
answer: No, that's where the oil goes.

question: Is it?
answer: I think so.

question: How are we doing, Wanda?
answer: Not good, Nick. Not bad, but not good. We need to finish this scene and do Scene thirty-one today.

question: Scene thirty-one?! I left my notes for Scene thirty-one at home! I didn't know we were --
answer: Nick, Nick. I'll send someone to your apartment to pick them up. Now, relax.

question: Oh, OK. Send somebody to my apartment to pick them up; it's the red notebook, under the bed.
answer: It's taken care of, Nick.

question: We're all lit, the smoke machine is under control; we're ready to go.
answer: What about the dolly?

question: Just need to see a run-through and we're all set. I'm going to make your job easy today, Wanda. Wandaful. Mmm, I'm glad you wore that perfume. And don't worry about Palomino; I'll take you to a jazz club tonight.
answer: Oh, I can't make it. I have to go see Chad; he's extremely ill.

question: Oh, by the way my eye's much better.
answer: Listen, Wolf, this may not be the best time to say this but our relationship is going nowhere.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Please, don't take it personally. Because I care for you, Wolf, I really do. But I've had this feeling for quite a while and I think it's time we ended it. OK? I think it's better.

question: So do I.
answer: Well, good. Still friends?

question: Sure.
answer: Great, cause we still have to work together and there's no reason it has to be unpleasant. Give me a hug. You're a real special guy, Wolf.

question: Thanks.
answer: OK, let's get the A Team in please! Nick, Ellen, Mr. Tito!

question: OK, here's the shot. We start wide with Ellen standing absolutely still right in the middle of the frame. You got that, Wolf?
answer: Yeah.

question: What happened to your eye?
answer: Nothing. It's a little sensitive today.

question: Can you see?
answer: Of course I can see!

question: Oh, OK; I guess I missed it. You could make it bigger if you want. And Ellen, maybe just a little more tension when you see him.
answer: I thought I didn't see him.

question: Right, maybe you see him a little bit.
answer: Alright, I'm confused. Do I see him or not?

question: You see him.
answer: OK, what is the tension? Who is Toto?

question: OK, what is the tension? Who is Toto?
answer: It's Tito.

question: What did I say?
answer: Toto.

question: Cut.
answer: That's a cut. Going again, Nick?

question: Yes.
answer: Going again, please stand by.

question: Well, it's not fake; it's real. Just remember, you really want the apple. Tito, I still think we could see more of a laugh at the end.
answer: What kind of laugh?

question: Just a laugh.
answer: Show me.

question: Oh, OK. A laugh. I'm thinking maybe like this. Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha. Something like that. OK? And remember, Tito, this is a dream. Not everything has to make sense. A laugh right there heightens our sense of... of...
answer: Anxiety.

question: I really don't like being spoken to like that, Nick!
answer: Yeah, well I don't like your attitude!

question: I don't have an attitude!
answer: The hell you don't! Every time I ask you to do something all I get is No, No, No and I'm sick of it! I hired you to do a job; if you're not going to do it you better let me know right now!

question: I'm sorry, Nick. I'm going through some heavy shit.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I can't really go into it. It's pretty heavy.
answer: Personal?

question: Personal, professional, emotional. It's doing a number on me. And now you're telling me you're going to fire me.
answer: I didn't say that, Wolf. Come on, I'm not going to fire you. You're doing a great job here.

question: Am I?
answer: Yeah, I don't know what I'd do without you, man. You've got a great eye. I just hope it's not the one under that eyepatch. Listen, Wolf. Let me tell you one thing I've learned; sometimes you just have to roll with things. You know?

question: You're right.
answer: Roll with it, man. You'll be OK.

question: How did you get here?
answer: I took a bus in; went right to your apartment.

question: How did you get out of your room?
answer: Oh, I just went right through the door.

question: It was unlocked!?
answer: No, it was locked. I just went through it. It's something I've learned to do, Nicky. I can walk through just about anything; like air.

question: Mom, you've got to stop doing this. I'm serious. I'm a little upset with you. You could have gotten lost, or hurt.
answer: I wanted to see you. I've missed you.

question: How's the smoke machine?
answer: It's dead, Nick. I've got calls out to every Effects house in the city but I just can't seem to locate --

question: Forget it. We'll shoot without it.
answer: But Nick, it's a Dream Sequence.

question: That's the way it goes, Wanda. We're just going to have to roll with it. Nothing else we can do. We've got to roll with it, right, Wolf? OK, here we go. Ellen, you've got to keep reaching for that apple. I don't feel that you really want it. I mean, Christ, how many times do I have to tell you!
answer: Everyone stand by. Nobody move. Going again, right away.

question: Alright, Nicole. What's the matter?
answer: You tell me! You're the one with the bug up your ass!

question: Now wait just a second!
answer: You've been picking on me all day! I can't do anything right!

question: I'm sorry if I was short with you, Nicole, but I think you can see I'm under a little pressure here. I'm shooting a Dream Sequence without a smoke machine, my mother's out there thinking she's at a circus wedding and you tell me the whole movie seems fake!
answer: I never said that!

question: You did too. You said, "Everything feels fake."
answer: I meant me! I feel fake! Everything I'm doing feels fake. I can't act. I should just do shower scenes in Richard Gere movies for the rest of my life!

question: Mom, listen to me. I don't want you to move from this chair. Do you understand?
answer: Oh Jesus, you sound just like your father...

question: Mom, I'm serious.
answer: OK, OK. I won't move.

question: Look, Tito. It's not that big a deal. It's a dream, alright. Strange things happen in a dream. All you have to do is laugh. Why is that such a problem?
answer: Why does it have to be a dwarf?

question: What?
answer: Why does my character have to be a dwarf?

question: He doesn't have to be a dwarf.
answer: Then why is he?! Is that the only way you can make this a dream; put a dwarf in it?

question: No, Tito; that's not --
answer: Have you ever had a dream with a dwarf in it?! Do you know anyone who's had a dream with a dwarf in it? NO! I don't even have dreams with dwarves in them! The only place I've seen dwarves in dreams is in stupid movies like this! Make it weird; put a dwarf in it. Everyone will go "whoa whoa whoa, must be a dream, there's a fucking dwarf in it!" Well, I'm sick of it. You can take this Dream Sequence and shove it up your ass!

question: And cut!! Wolf, talk to me, man! Did you get it?
answer: Got it, Nick! Everything!

question: The Close-up?
answer: Perfect. See? That's what I meant about going hand-held!

question: Alright everyone, listen up. That is a wrap on Scene Six.
answer: Hold it! Hold it! Hold it!

question: What?!
answer: I need to record room tone. I'll need thirty seconds of silence.

question: MS Nicole. She jerks her head slightly in response to this moment of thought.
answer: Wolf, I'm sorry! Please forgive me! I love you, Wolf! Please! Give me one more chance. Let me prove it! I love you! I love you, Wolf!

question: MS Wolf. He glances furtively at Wanda with a trace of hope still in his eyes.
answer: What I love about you, Chad, is you're not afraid of my power.
